content: The "Teachers and First Responders Back to Work Act of 2012" authorizes grants to States for preventing teacher layoffs and creating jobs in public education for the 2012-2014 school years. The Secretary reserves a small percentage of funds for assistance to outlying areas and the Secretary of the Interior for activities consistent with the title. The Secretary reserves funds for assistance to outlying areas and the Secretary of the Interior for activities in schools funded by the Bureau of Indian Education. Additionally, a portion of funds is allocated for administration and oversight, with a maximum of $2,000,000 for each fiscal year. The Secretary determines award amounts for each State based on a specific allocation formula. The Secretary allocates funds to each State based on the population of individuals aged 5 through 17 and the State's total population. If a State does not receive a grant, the Secretary reallocates the funds. If a State does not receive a grant, the Secretary will reallocate the funds to other States that received grants using a specific formula. SEC. 103. STATE APPLICATION. State chief executives must submit an application to the Secretary within 30 days of this Act's enactment to request a grant. The application must include specific information and an assurance that the State will maintain support for education at or above the level of fiscal year 2011 for fiscal years 2012 and 2013. State chief executives must submit an application to the Secretary within 30 days of this Act's enactment to request a grant. The application must include specific information and an assurance that the State will maintain support for education at or above the level of fiscal year 2011 for fiscal years 2012 and 2013. If a chief executive of a State does not wish to receive a grant under this title, they must submit a letter to the Secretary within 30 days of the Act's enactment. The letter should state their decision and reasons for not seeking the grant. The Act requires State chief executives to submit an application for a grant within 30 days of enactment. If a chief executive does not want the grant, they must submit a letter to the Secretary explaining their decision. The Secretary has the authority to waive the assurance requirement under certain circumstances like natural disasters or financial decline in the State. SEC. 104. STATE GRANTS. Each State receiving a grant under this title must reserve a portion for State-funded early learning programs and administrative costs. The remaining funds are to be used for awards to local educational agencies for early childhood, elementary, and secondary public education support. The State must reserve a portion of the grant for State-funded early learning programs and administrative costs. The remaining funds are allocated to local educational agencies based on enrollment ratios. The State reserves a portion of the grant for early learning programs and administrative costs. The remaining funds are allocated to local educational agencies based on enrollment ratios. The State reserves a portion of the grant for early learning programs and administrative costs, allocating the remaining funds to local educational agencies based on enrollment ratios. States receiving grants under this title must make subgrants available to local educational agencies within 100 days. Prohibitions include using grant funds to establish or supplement rainy-day funds. The State cannot use grant funds to establish, restore, or supplement a rainy-day fund, reduce or retire State debt obligations, or supplant State funds to reduce or retire debt obligations. SEC. 105. Local educational agency subgrants are to be used for retaining, recalling, or hiring employees for educational services. Funds must be obligated by September 30, 2014. SEC. 106. Early learning programs. SEC. 106. Early learning programs funded under this title must use funds for retaining, recalling, or hiring early childhood educators. Funds must be obligated by September 30, 2014. SEC. 107. REPORTING. States receiving grants under this title must submit reports to the Secretary by September 30 of 2013 and 2014 detailing how funds were used and the number of jobs supported. SEC. 108. DEFINITIONS. Defines terms such as "local educational agency", "outlying area", "State educational agency", and "State-funded early learning program". SEC. 109. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. $30,000,000,000 authorized for grant program in fiscal years 2012 and 2013. TITLE II - FIRST RESPONDER STABILIZATION. SEC. 201. Funds provided to States and localities to prevent layoffs and create jobs for law enforcement officers and firefighters. SEC. 202. FIREFIGHTER GRANT PROGRAM. The Secretary of Homeland Security is authorized to make competitive grants to hire, rehire, and retain firefighters and maintain resources for fire departments. The Secretary may waive certain requirements in the Federal Fire Prevention and Control Act. Additional funds are authorized for grants under the Act. Authorization of $1,000,000,000 for grants under the Federal Fire Prevention and Control Act for fiscal years 2012 and 2013, with a portion reserved for administrative costs. SEC. 203. LAW ENFORCEMENT OFFICER GRANT PROGRAM. The Attorney General will provide competitive grants to hire, rehire, and retain law enforcement officers under the Law Enforcement Officer Grant Program. Appropriations are authorized for this purpose in addition to funds already allocated for similar grants. In addition to funds already allocated for similar grants, $4,000,000,000 is authorized to be appropriated for fiscal years 2012 and 2013 under the Law Enforcement Officer Grant Program. The Attorney General will reserve up to $8,000,000 each year for administrative costs.
